author: By Matthew Futterman
title: After a Rough Year, New York Road Runners Searches for a Leader and Mission
description: After the coronavirus pandemic halted the club’s marquee events, the organizers of the New York City Marathon began trying to reclaim their roots and reconnect with the local community.
content: Not very long ago, there was a pretty strong case to be made that New York Road Runners, the organization that owns and stages the New York City Marathon, was the de facto leader of running in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: How Slowing Down Helped Marathoner Molly Seidel Speed Up
description: The American runner says she owes her Olympic bronze medal to her coach, Jon Green, who turned her training approach upside down. New York’s 26.2 miles could be her toughest challenge yet.
content: Molly Seidel and Jon Green hashed out their grand plan over several cups of coffee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: ‘Much Obliged!’
description: Brooke Husic and Will Nediger put on a Saturday puzzle spectacular.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is one of those Saturday grids that I like to kvell over with everyone. It’s the first Times collaboration between two constructors, Brooke Husic and Will Nediger, both of whom just get better and better. The majority of entries lit a spark in me, be it of recognition or discovery, or the one when you get the joke after what feels like eons. So satisfying, and it’s good to know from their notes that there are more co-constructions out in the puzzleverse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: Young Women Are Leading Climate Protests. Guess Who Runs Global Talks?
description: There’s a clear gender and generation gap at the Glasgow talks, and the two sides have very different views on how to address global warming.
content: GLASGOW — The week began with more than 130 presidents and prime ministers posing for a group photo in a century-old Baroque museum crafted from red sandstone. Fewer than 10 were women. Their median age, as their host at the climate summit, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson, reminded them, was over 60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Maria Jimenez Moya
title: ‘No Way Out’: A Sudden Life-and-Death Struggle at a Houston Concert
description: Eight people died at Travis Scott’s Astroworld festival, and hundreds more were injured as investigators sought to determine why and how a surging crowd turned deadly.
content: HOUSTON — Panic and then desperation spread through the crowd of 50,000 mostly young people just as the popular hometown rapper they had come to see, Travis Scott, took the stage Friday night. It came like a wave, an unstoppable movement of bodies that could not be held back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Lights Out: 5 New ‘Dark-Sky Places’ for Top-Shelf Stargazing
description: The International Dark-Sky Association awards certifications to sites with exceptionally high-quality night skies, including national parks, sanctuaries and reserves.
content: Vast expanses of glittering stars. Pristine views of the night sky. And no glare to muddy the Milky Way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Americans Are Flush With Cash and Jobs. They Also Think the Economy Is Awful.
description: The psychological effects of inflation seem to have the upper hand.
content: Americans are, by many measures, in a better financial position than they have been in many years. They also believe the economy is in terrible shape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Carl Hulse
title: How a $1 Trillion Infrastructure Bill Survived an Intraparty Brawl
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi agreed to a deal proposed by the Congressional Black Caucus, mobilizing one faction of Democratic lawmakers to win over two others.
content: WASHINGTON — Another showdown day over President Biden’s ambitious domestic agenda dawned Friday full of optimism, even after the drubbing that Democrats took in the off-year elections on Tuesday. But by afternoon, lawmakers again seemed stuck when leaders of the Congressional Black Caucus entered Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Spanish Police Seek Missing Plane Passengers After Emergency Landing
description: More than 20 people fled a Moroccan flight that diverted to Mallorca after a passenger apparently fell ill. A dozen had yet to be found.
content: MADRID — The Spanish police were searching on Saturday for a dozen passengers on a flight from Morocco to Turkey who fled into the Spanish island of Mallorca after their plane made an emergency landing at the airport there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Mark Glaze, Influential Gun Control Advocate, Dies at 51
description: As the executive director of Everytown for Gun Safety, he took on the National Rifle Association and helped make gun violence a winning issue.
content: Mark Glaze, who was widely considered a founding figure in the modern gun-control movement, died on Oct. 31 in Scranton, Pa. He was 51.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaime Yaya Barry and Ruth Maclean
title: Tanker Truck Explodes in Sierra Leone, Killing at Least 98
description: The truck first started leaking fuel and people had rushed to collect it, an official said. Many of them died in the blast, along with others nearby.
content: At least 98 people were killed when a tanker truck exploded on Friday night after a crash in the capital of Sierra Leone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport and Christopher Flavelle
title: Infrastructure Bill Makes First Major U.S. Investment in Climate Resilience
description: The measure includes $47 billion to help communities prepare for the new age of extreme fires, floods, storms and droughts that scientists say are worsened by human-caused climate change.
content: WASHINGTON — The $1 trillion infrastructure bill now headed to President Biden’s desk includes the largest amount of money ever spent by the United States to prepare the nation to withstand the devastating impacts of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: In a Region in Strife, India’s Moral High Ground Erodes
description: The hard-line attitude of Narendra Modi’s ruling party toward Muslims has undermined the nation’s reputation as a voice for tolerance in South Asia.
content: NEW DELHI — The mob rampaged for days, burning homes, breaking into temples and clashing with police, leaving several dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Gandel
title: Berkshire Hathaway’s Profit Fell in the Third Quarter
description: The conglomerate’s results reflected the turmoil in financial markets and the broader slowdown in U.S. economic growth.
content: Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett, on Saturday reported a sharp decrease in earnings in the third quarter, reflecting the turbulent financial markets as well as a slowdown in the U.S. economic recovery with a spike in Covid-19 cases. Profits fell by a third to $10 billion, down from $30 billion in the same three months of 2020, when the economy was still in the process of reopening from pandemic shutdowns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hari Kumar and Emily Schmall
title: A fire in Covid intensive care ward kills 11 people in India.
description: Staff at the hospital in the western state of Maharashtra tried to douse the fire with fire extinguishers, but the flames spread quickly in the airtight room.
content: NEW DELHI — Eleven people died after a fire broke out in a coronavirus intensive care unit in the western state of Maharashtra, the latest in a series of fatal disasters in Covid-19 wards in India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Jackson
title: Keeping Hope Alive in Glasgow
description: A dispatch from the protests outside COP26.
content: Hello from Glasgow. We’re dedicating this newsletter to COP26, the United Nations conference happening here this week and next, which we covered on the show on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: On Spain’s Camino de Santiago, Even Óscar the Donkey Is a Pilgrim
description: An artist and an innkeeper have enlisted the help of a burro in their effort to rescue the traditions of Spain’s ancient pilgrimage route from mass tourism (and selfies).
content: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA, Spain — Of all those journeying along the Camino de Santiago, a fabled route that attracts thousands of pilgrims each year, few are quite like Óscar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Eric Garner’s Mother Wanted Answers for His Death. She Isn’t Satisfied.
description: An inquiry into the killing of Mr. Garner in 2014 ended on Friday after the testimony of a dozen witnesses. Here are five takeaways.
content: The death of Eric Garner has reverberated with unanswered questions and fresh developments over the seven years since a New York police officer placed him in a banned chokehold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and Erika P. Rodriguez
title: A Turtle, a Pool and the Fight to Save Puerto Rico’s Beaches
description: An attempt to rebuild a beachfront pool turned into a much bigger story about the threats of erosion and overdevelopment on the island.
content: RINCÓN, P.R. — The turtle, presumably, had no way of knowing it would become a symbol of protest when it got stuck for hours in a construction site on a beach in western Puerto Rico, unable to return to the sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Trump Justice Dept. Official Defies Request by Jan. 6 Panel
description: Jeffrey Clark, who aided in the former president’s efforts to overturn the election, appeared before the committee but would not answer substantive questions.
content: WASHINGTON — Jeffrey Clark, a former Justice Department official involved in former President Donald J. Trump’s frenzied efforts to overturn the 2020 presidential election, refused to cooperate on Friday with the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, leading to a sharp rebuke from the committee’s chairman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Body Shaming Dressed Up as a Fitness Goal Is Still Body Shaming
description: When women are urged to change their bodies to perform, is it really about aesthetics?
content: The University of Oregon is known for its track and field program. The women’s team has won two national titles since Robert Johnson took the helm of the program in 2012, and the university’s athletic programs enjoy significant financial support from Nike (whose co-founder Phil Knight is an alumnus). Hayward Field, the home of the Oregon Ducks’ track, hosted the Olympic Trials in 2021 and will be the location of the World Athletics Championships in 2022.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Who Won What in the Bipartisan Infrastructure Deal
description: The bipartisan infrastructure bill has passed. Now it's time for Democratic centrists to make a good-faith deal on the Build Back Better bill.
content: Finally! After months of excruciating negotiations, President Biden gets to take a victory lap in celebration of his own Big Freaking Deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch and Isabella Grullón Paz
title: A court temporarily blocks Biden’s vaccine mandate.
description: A stay granted by a federal appeals court in Louisiana could signal an uphill battle for the administration in getting the entire American work force vaccinated.
content: A federal appeals panel on Saturday temporarily blocked a new coronavirus vaccine mandate for large businesses, in a sign that the Biden administration may face an uphill battle in its biggest effort yet to combat the virus among the American work force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky and Megan Specia
title: Activists hope protests will draw large crowds as leaders haggle in Glasgow.
description: Protest organizers hoped to draw large crowds to the streets of Glasgow on Saturday to demand urgent action against a climate crisis that is already flooding cities, wiping towns off the map, destroying forests, and fueling storms, heat waves and droughts around the world.
content: Protest organizers hoped to draw large crowds to the streets of Glasgow on Saturday to demand urgent action against a climate crisis that is already flooding cities, wiping towns off the map, destroying forests, and fueling storms, heat waves and droughts around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Zach Montague
title: In Infrastructure Votes, 19 Members Broke With Their Party
description: The defectors who crossed partisan lines in Congress include 13 Republicans who supported the bill and the six liberal members of “The Squad,” who opposed it.
content: WASHINGTON — Infrastructure funding has traditionally been a broadly bipartisan issue on Capitol Hill, but on Friday night President Biden’s sweeping infrastructure bill passed mostly along party lines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Celebrates Infrastructure Win, Even if Harder Victory Is Ahead
description: “Finally! Infrastructure week!” the president declared with a broad smile.
content: President Biden celebrated the passage of the $1 trillion infrastructure bill on Saturday, declaring — just days after an electoral drubbing for his party — that he had made good on two key promises of his campaign: reviving the economy and getting the nation vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter and Tony Luong
title: Can Progress on Diversity Be Union-Made?
description: In Boston, setting a goal for a racially diverse construction work force is one thing. Meeting it has proved more difficult.
content: Staring at the wall of glass clawing its way up the unfinished facade of the Winthrop Center in downtown Boston — 53 floors of commercial and residential space soaring 690 feet — Travis Watson isn’t interested in the grandeur of the thing. He wants to know who’s working on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Democrats Choosing Less Risky Path on Drug Prices
description: Experts say recent compromises could create less harm in balancing innovation with profits.
content: In early budget negotiations, it looked as if the Democrats were finally going to take on Big Pharma over spiraling drug prices. Then last week, drug pricing fell out of the bill altogether and it looked as if the drug companies had won again. Now there is a compromise that looks modest but could have real bite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Costa Rica moves to require Covid shots for children.
description: The Central American nation’s health ministry said on Friday it was adding Covid-19 to the list of required vaccinations for people 18 and younger.
content: Costa Rican officials said on Friday that they would require Covid-19 vaccinations for people under 18 “to safeguard the best interests” of children, becoming one of the first countries to implement such a mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Foster Kamer
title: Are You Anxious, Avoidant or Secure?
description: Over a decade after its publication, one book on dating has people firmly in its grip.
content: Most articles don’t, for good reason, start with “My therapist said….”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Facing a spike in infections, Austria sharpens the rules of its Covid pass.
description: Austrians will need proof of vaccination or a past infection to be seated at a restaurant, enter a bar, visit a hairdresser or join any gathering of more than 25 people.
content: Austria is tightening the rules of a national vaccine pass program starting Monday as it attempts to stem a coronavirus surge that has brought cases to levels unseen in almost a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Sui-Lee Wee
title: ‘A Daily Cloud of Suffering’: A Crackdown in China Is Felt Abroad
description: As Uyghurs grapple with the emotional trauma of their families suffering back in Xinjiang, some are overcoming a cultural stigma to seek out counseling.
content: Mustafa Aksu was already sinking into depression when he learned of the successive deaths of his brother, uncle and two cousins back home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Megan Specia
title: COP26 Protesters Back an Array of Causes, Connected by Climate Change
description: Thousands gathered in the rain in Glasgow to press the case for more urgent and meaningful action by world leaders in response to global warming.
content: GLASGOW — Defying biting wind and steady rain, tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets of Glasgow on Saturday in noisy and colorful protests, calling on global leaders to take action drastic enough to match the scale of a climate crisis already wreaking havoc on parts of the globe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Big Kid Vaccines Are Here!
description: Rejoicing (mostly) ensues.
content: When I woke up Wednesday morning, my mom text threads were already on fire with the news that CVS and Walgreens had opened up Covid vaccine appointments for kids 5 and up. I felt a profound sense of relief as I nabbed slots for my 5- and 8-year-olds, and I wasn’t the only one. J. David Goodman, The New York Times Houston bureau chief, was on hand at Texas Children’s Hospital to see some of the first shots doled out to elementary schoolers in the United States. “This is the best day ever!” one child said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monique Jaques
title: For Carli Lloyd, Creative Tributes Abound as Retirement Approaches
description: The soccer star’s hometown gave a party in her honor, her employers moved a home game to a different state, and her teammates have been wearing her jersey number.
content: DELRAN, N.J. — Chants of “Car-li Loyd! Car-li Loyd! Car-li Loyd!” filled Delran Community Park on Oct. 14, led primarily by the children from Delran F.C., a South Jersey youth soccer club that was Carli Lloyd’s first team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Nocera
title: An Environmental Hero or Outlaw? Can It Be Both?
description: Steven Donziger, who won a $9.5 billion settlement against Chevron over dumped oil, began serving a six-month sentence for contempt of court last week.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Unmoved by Climate Promises, Activists Hit Glasgow’s Streets
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 6, 2021.
content: “We can’t play politics with this kind of issue. Climate change — it surpasses every other issue we have.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Richard Fausset
title: Georgia Grand Jury Looms in Trump Inquiry
description: An Atlanta D.A. is said to be likely to impanel a special grand jury in her criminal investigation of election interference by the former president and his allies.
content: As the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 Capitol riot fights to extract testimony and documents from Donald J. Trump’s White House, an Atlanta district attorney is moving toward convening a special grand jury in her criminal investigation of election interference by the former president and his allies, according to a person with direct knowledge of the deliberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Foreman Says Military Jury Was Disgusted by C.I.A. Torture
description: A Navy captain whose letter recommended clemency for a Qaeda terrorist drafted the damning two-page document in 20 minutes.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — A Navy captain who as head of a jury in a war-crimes court wrote a damning letter calling the C.I.A.’s torture of a terrorist “a stain on the moral fiber of America” said his views are typical of senior members of the U.S. military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon and Shane Goldmacher
title: Democrats Thought They Bottomed Out in Rural, White America. It Wasn’t the Bottom.
description: Republicans ran up the margins in rural Virginia counties, the latest sign that Democrats, as one lawmaker put it, “continue to tank in small-town America.”
content: HOT SPRINGS, Va. — The increasingly liberal politics of Virginia had been a sore spot for residents of this conservative town of 499 people nestled in the Allegheny Mountains. But this past week, as Republicans stormed to marquee victories powered in part by turnout in rural areas like Bath County, local voters cheered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: How to watch U.F.C. 268 or Canelo Álvarez vs. Caleb Plant.
description: The fights are available on a variety of streaming services and from other television providers.
content: (Follow U.F.C. 268 live for our coverage of Usman vs. Covington)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Wokeness Derails the Democrats
description: Out of chaos comes just more chaos.
content: WASHINGTON — In Shakespeare, when characters want to fulfill their desires, they escape to what’s been called the Green World.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan O'Callaghan
title: Star System With Right-Angled Planets Surprises Astronomers
description: Two planets orbit the poles while another revolves around the star’s equator, suggesting a mysterious, undetected force.
content: Star systems come in all shapes and sizes. Some have lots of planets, some have larger planets and others have no planets at all. But a particularly unusual system about 150 light-years from our own has scientists scratching their heads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker, Steve Eder, David D. Kirkpatrick and Arya Sundaram
title: How Police Justify Killing Drivers: The Vehicle Was a Weapon
description: A Times investigation into a common defense for shooting motorists found that some officers had put themselves in danger. Others appeared to face no peril at all.
content: PHENIX CITY, Ala. — On a Sunday in May 2017, a patrol car sat outside the city’s oldest public housing project, waiting for anyone acting suspiciously. The two police officers heard Cedric Mifflin before they saw him, blasting music from a silver Mercury Grand Marquis. Then they tried to pull him over: He wasn’t wearing a seatbelt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How Do I Get My Landlord to Compensate Me?
description: When you pay for something the landlord should have provided, withholding rent may spur action — though it’s not without risk.
content: Q: For the past 15 years, I have lived in a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan. In early July, my oven broke and I texted the super. A few weeks later, after nothing was fixed, I contacted the managing agent requesting the repair and a rent reduction. It wasn’t until October that a functional oven was finally delivered, and I paid my rent with a note explaining that I was deducting $200 to cover the cost of a toaster oven, which I bought as a temporary solution. I got back a certified letter asking me to pay the $200, plus $155 in legal fees. Can I fight this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: An 8-Year-Old Explains the Metaverse
description: “One minute you get scammed, another minute you’re having the best time of your life, making billions of dollars.”
content: Like a lot of people, I have been scrambling to get a grasp of the metaverse since Mark Zuckerberg made his move to colonize it by rebranding Facebook as Meta last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt, William K. Rashbaum, Adam Goldman and Ben Protess
title: F.B.I. Searches James O’Keefe’s Home in Ashley Biden Diary Theft Inquiry
description: Authorities carried out a court-ordered search at the New York apartment of the Project Veritas founder two days after searching the homes of his associates.
content: Federal authorities on Saturday searched the home of James O’Keefe, the founder of the conservative group Project Veritas, according to witnesses and people briefed on the matter, a day after Mr. O’Keefe acknowledged that the group was under investigation by the Justice Department in connection with a diary reported to have been stolen from Ashley Biden, President Biden’s daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler, Emily Cochrane and Zach Montague
title: This Is Where the States Want Billions in Infrastructure Funding Spent
description: The plan finally approved on Friday will address transportation, water, broadband, energy and public safety needs that have been building for years, sometimes decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christian Lorentzen
title: Padgett Powell Goes Snake Chasing
description: The novelist’s first nonfiction book, “Indigo,” collects wide-ranging essays unified by his unmistakable voice.
content: INDIGO Arm Wrestling, Snake Saving, and Some Things in Between By Padgett Powell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: PinkPantheress Has 1 Million Fans on TikTok
description: Her songs “Just for Me” and “Break It Off” were breakout summer hits.
content: Name: PinkPantheress
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: How I Became Extremely Open-Minded
description: Fighting for my health, I went to the fringe without rejecting the center.
content: When you have a chronic illness and struggle to get better, you try to maintain a certain equilibrium by distinguishing yourself from all those other sick people, the ones who are trying truly crazy things while you are proceeding sensibly and moderately along the path to health.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheila Yasmin Marikar
title: If You Sell ‘Oaxaca in a Bottle,’ What Happens to Oaxaca?
description: Mezcal is soaring in popularity far from the agave fields in Mexico.
content: “Nobody dare order a margarita with any of these, or I will be really upset.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: This and That
description: Sid Sivakumar makes a sweet Sunday puzzle debut.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — For everyone who wanted more flourishes and scintillations after yesterday, here is a big treat of a puzzle filled with counters, decks, a scale, a chest — everything but a theme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Johnson Sirleaf
title: This Is What Africa Needs Right Now
description: World leaders must seize the moral imperative and commit to action on climate change.
content: How do you tell people that they must leave their community or drown? This was the gut-wrenching decision I faced five years ago, as president of Liberia, when thousands of families in the capital’s largest township saw their homes swept out to sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Hajdu
title: McCartney, With and Without Lennon
description: In “The Lyrics: 1956 to the Present,” Paul McCartney and the poet Paul Muldoon present the words to 154 of the former Beatle’s songs.
content: THE LYRICS 1956 to the Present By Paul McCartney Edited and with an introduction by Paul Muldoon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: High Schoolers Barred From Hockey Games After Crudely Taunting a Goalie
description: After students at a Pennsylvania high school yelled sexually explicit chants at a visiting team’s only female player, the entire student body was barred from games for the rest of the season.
content: The entire student body of a Pennsylvania junior-senior high school has been barred from attending classmates’ hockey games after some students chanted sexually explicit vulgarities at a visiting team’s goalie — the team’s only female player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: Is It Just Us or Does Everyone Have a Cold Right Now?
description: Because misery loves company.
content: A nasty cold hit New York City and much of the country this summer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio and Alicia Parlapiano
title: How Every House Member Voted on the Infrastructure Bill
description: The $1 trillion package passed with the support of nearly all Democrats and 13 Republicans.
content: The $1 trillion package passed with the support of nearly all Democrats and 13 Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: Behind the Scenes: Police Traffic Stops
description: I drove to Alabama and met one of my colleagues, Donovan Thomas. Here’s what happened.
content: I drove to Alabama and met one of my colleagues, Donovan Thomas. Here’s what happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: On the Scene: Climate Protests
description: The protests related to COP26, the United Nations climate summit, peaked on Friday and Saturday, drawing tens of thousands of people to Glasgow’s streets.
content: The protests related to COP26, the United Nations climate summit, peaked on Friday and Saturday, drawing tens of thousands of people to Glasgow’s streets.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Officer Michael Seavers’s Statement
description: The officer’s account of the traffic stop that ended in the fatal shooting of Cedric Mifflin.
content: The officer’s account of the traffic stop that ended in the fatal shooting of Cedric Mifflin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nailah Morgan and Christina Kelso
title: At Least 8 People Killed at Astroworld Music Festival
description: Several people died and dozens of others were injured at the Travis Scott concert in Houston, after a large crowd began pushing toward the front of the stage. Video showed crowds amassing earlier in the day, as about 50,000 people attended the festival.
content: Several people died and dozens of others were injured at the Travis Scott concert in Houston, after a large crowd began pushing toward the front of the stage. Video showed crowds amassing earlier in the day, as about 50,000 people attended the festival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Tanker Truck Explosion Kills at Least 98 People in Sierra Leone
description: Many of the victims were motorcyclists and taxi drivers who were trying to collect fuel leaking from the truck at the time of the explosion, according to an official. The truck started leaking after colliding with another vehicle.
content: Many of the victims were motorcyclists and taxi drivers who were trying to collect fuel leaking from the truck at the time of the explosion, according to an official. The truck started leaking after colliding with another vehicle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Protesters in Glasgow Demand Climate Action
description: Protesters took to the streets of Glasgow near the COP26 conference to urge world leaders to take immediate action to combat the climate crisis. More than 100,000 marched in the city, organizers said.
content: Protesters took to the streets of Glasgow near the COP26 conference to urge world leaders to take immediate action to combat the climate crisis. More than 100,000 marched in the city, organizers said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Nov. 6, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 6, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about an increase in rates on some government savings bonds misstated the URL for the website Treasury Direct. It is TreasuryDirect.gov, not TreasuryDirect.com.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Way We Work Now (or Don’t)
description: Ways of thinking about work, and antiwork. Also: Is Facebook being prejudged?
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
